docs.snippet: Whether Jeffrey K. Skilling helped himself on the stand more than he hurt his defense will ultimately depend on how the jury weighs his personality....
docs.lead_paragraph: In eight days on the witness stand Jeffrey K. Skilling accomplished much of what he needed to do in front of the jury hearing his criminal case, avoiding any major gaffes while staunchly maintaining his innocence. But in the end, the performance by Enron's former chief executive was far from perfect, and may have revealed to the jury more than he and his lawyer wanted.

headline.main: Which Picture of Skilling Will Enron Jurors Believe?

byline.original: By ALEXEI BARRIONUEVO; Vikas Bajaj and Kurt Eichenwald contributed reporting from New York for this article

docs.snippet: Most former Enron employees have been unable to restore the glitter of their old jobs....
docs.lead_paragraph: For Angelique Chappell, a former administrative assistant at Enron, it all now seems like a mirage. There were the trips organized just for assistants, including one to California to visit a new chain of hotels where they would be booking reservations for their bosses. There was the time she won a company drawing for seats behind the dugout at a Houston Astros baseball game in a stadium then known as Enron Field. And, she recalls, there were the American Express gift cards that were handed out frequently to those who answered a trivia question.

headline.main: Hard Times Haunt Enron's Ex-Workers; Few Find Jobs of Equal Stature Years After Company's Collapse

docs.snippet: To the Editor:    After reading ''The Last Days of Enron'' (March 13), I had the uncomfortable feeling that perhaps in two years we might be reading an article titled ''The Last Days of the U.S.A.'' Maybe that day will come even sooner, considerin...
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: After reading ''The Last Days of Enron'' (March 13), I had the uncomfortable feeling that perhaps in two years we might be reading an article titled ''The Last Days of the U.S.A.'' Maybe that day will come even sooner, considering the mismanagement of the finances of our country.
docs.abstract: Cornelia Smollin letter comments on March 13 article on last days of Enron

docs.snippet: Lea Fastow, the wife of Enron's former chief financial officer, began a one-year prison term yesterday for her role in the accounting fraud that forced the company to seek bankruptcy protection in 2001.      Mrs. Fastow, 42, a former Enron assista...
docs.lead_paragraph: Lea Fastow, the wife of Enron's former chief financial officer, began a one-year prison term yesterday for her role in the accounting fraud that forced the company to seek bankruptcy protection in 2001. Mrs. Fastow, 42, a former Enron assistant treasurer, entered the Federal Criminal Detention Center in downtown Houston at 8:20 a.m. Central time. She pleaded guilty in May to not reporting some income that her husband, Andrew S. Fastow, had earned as a result of his participation in an accounting fraud.
docs.abstract: Lea Fastow, wife of Enron Corp's former chief financial officer Andrew S Fastow, begins one-year prison term at Federal Criminal Detention Center, Houston, for her role in accounting fraud that forced company to seek bankruptcy protection in 2001; photo (M)

headline.main: Ex-Officer's Wife Begins Prison Term In Enron Case

docs.snippet: An article last Sunday about Lea Fastow, the former assistant treasurer of Enron, misstated the prison term facing her husband, Andrew S. Fastow, the company's former chief financial officer, as part of a plea bargain agreement. It is 10 years, no...
docs.lead_paragraph: An article last Sunday about Lea Fastow, the former assistant treasurer of Enron, misstated the prison term facing her husband, Andrew S. Fastow, the company's former chief financial officer, as part of a plea bargain agreement. It is 10 years, not ''up to'' 10 years.
docs.abstract: Correction of June 20 article on Lea Fastow's prison term; her husband, Andrew S Fastow, faces sentence of 10 years, not up to 10 years

docs.snippet: The logjam blocking an important step forward in the government's criminal investigation into the collapse of Enron showed tentative signs of breaking on Thursday.     A federal judge here said he would allow Lea Fastow, the wife of Enron's former...
docs.lead_paragraph: The logjam blocking an important step forward in the government's criminal investigation into the collapse of Enron showed tentative signs of breaking on Thursday. A federal judge here said he would allow Lea Fastow, the wife of Enron's former chief financial officer, to plead guilty to a single tax violation, but he signaled that he had not yet decided whether he would feel bound by the agreement she reached with prosecutors on a five-month sentence.
docs.abstract: Federal Judge David Hittner will allow Lea Fastow, wife of Enron Corp's former chief financial officer Andrew Fastow, to plead guilty to single tax violation, but signals he will not yet decide whether he will feel bound by agreement she reached with prosecutors on five-month sentence; photo (M)

headline.main: Judge Moves to Allow Plea By Wife of Ex-Enron Officer

docs.snippet: A bankruptcy judge today authorized the committee representing employees of the Enron Corporation to collect some of an estimated $53 million in accelerated deferred compensation payments set aside for certain executives on the eve of the company'...
docs.lead_paragraph: A bankruptcy judge today authorized the committee representing employees of the Enron Corporation to collect some of an estimated $53 million in accelerated deferred compensation payments set aside for certain executives on the eve of the company's bankruptcy filing, lawyers said. The judge, Arthur J. Gonzalez of Federal Bankruptcy Court in New York, approved a settlement reached by Enron's management, the creditors' committee and the employee committee, according to lawyers for the employees.
docs.abstract: Federal Bankruptcy Judge Arthur J Gonzalez authorizes committee representing employees of Enron Corp to collect some of estimated $53 million in accelerated deferred compensation payments set aside for certain executives on eve of company's bankruptcy filing (S)

docs.snippet: The Enron Corporation said yesterday that it planned to sell its 50-story headquarters in downtown Houston. Enron has occupied the tower, which has 1.27 million square feet of space, since 1985. Through a complex arrangement, it is owned by Brazos...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Enron Corporation said yesterday that it planned to sell its 50-story headquarters in downtown Houston. Enron has occupied the tower, which has 1.27 million square feet of space, since 1985. Through a complex arrangement, it is owned by Brazos Holdings, but Enron's major creditors will receive most of the proceeds of the sale, said Richard Rudd, senior managing director in the Houston office of Granite Partners, a real estate firm hired by Enron to handle the sale. Mr. Rudd said he expected the building to sell for ''somewhere over $100 million.'' Enron plans to move to another building in Houston, next March.
docs.abstract: Enron Corp plans to sell its 50-story headquarters in downtown Houston; estimated worth is over $100 million; plans to move to another building in Houston in March 2004 (S)

headline.main: ENRON PLANS TO SELL ITS HEADQUARTERS IN HOUSTON

docs.snippet: WHILE Americans have become ever more dependent upon electricity in their daily lives, a crucial part of the system that supports their way of life has not kept up.    Yes, the country has built more power plants -- enough to create a glut of powe...
docs.lead_paragraph: WHILE Americans have become ever more dependent upon electricity in their daily lives, a crucial part of the system that supports their way of life has not kept up. Yes, the country has built more power plants -- enough to create a glut of power in most parts of the country. But the transmission system -- a collection of high-voltage networks that connect the power plants where the electricity is produced to the local distribution companies that deliver it to homes and businesses -- is caught in the middle of the stalled deregulation of the American electric power industry.
docs.abstract: Daniel Yergin and Larry Makovich article says last week's blackout points up vulnerability of high-voltage wires that connect various regions of nation's power transmssion system, which was built to serve regulated monopolies and is now being called on to serve deregulated market; says conversion of transmission system to new role has been impeded by California's disastrous partial energy deregulation and role played by Enron and other energy marketing companies in power crisis; photos (M)

headline.main: The Nation; The System Did Not Fail. Yet the System Failed.

byline.original: By DANIEL YERGIN and LAWRENCE MAKOVICH

docs.snippet: The Enron Corporation's bankrupt broadband unit failed to identify millions of dollars in equipment on appraisal forms used to determine property taxes, a Harris County grand jury asserted in an indictment returned today.     The indictment accuse...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Enron Corporation's bankrupt broadband unit failed to identify millions of dollars in equipment on appraisal forms used to determine property taxes, a Harris County grand jury asserted in an indictment returned today. The indictment accused Enron Broadband Services of filing a business statement in April 2001 that failed to properly account for telecommunications equipment kept in a Houston warehouse. The broadband unit is among the subsidiaries that went bankrupt last year with the parent company.
docs.abstract: Grand jury issues indictment asserting that Enron Corp's bankrupt broadband unit failed to identify millions of dollars in equipment on appraisal forms used to determine property taxes due Harris County, Tex; accuses Enron Broadband Services of filing business statement in April 2001 that failed to properly account for telecommunications equipment kept in Houston warehouse (S)

headline.main: Enron Unit Indicted Over Tax Appraisals
